TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}

S.FORM: izua azua vatu a nakitjuqizing, aya a tjautsikel.
izoa azoa vato a nakitjoqizing, aya a tjaocikel.
S.TRANSL: There were some dogs which had belonged to Qizing village (OA; or which had been usurped), according to the story.

S.FORM: izua i Paliłaliław a vatu.
izoa i Paliljaliljaw a vato.
S.TRANSL: There were dogs in the Lower Paiwan area.

S.FORM: saka nu qemałup, nu qaqatsaqatsaan a vavuy a venan a takets, lingełen nua vatu a pasa dudut tua qinałan; sa djadjasi sa kani a mapułat.
saka no qemaljop, no qaqacaqacaan a vavoy a venan a takec, lingeljen noa vato a pasa dodot toa qinaljan; sa djadjasi sa kani a mapoljat.
S.TRANSL: When there was hunting, the big wild pigs, deer and muntjacs were surrounded and driven by the dogs to near the village, and were all caught and eaten.

S.FORM: azua nu kasi tsadja, inika makakatsu tu qaqatsaqatsaan.
azoa no kasi cadja, inika makakaco to qaqacaqacaan.
S.TRANSL: When they came from a distance, they couldn’t carry the big ones;

S.FORM: avan nu sika lemingeł a pasa dudut tua tapaw.
avan no sika lemingelj a pasa dodot toa tapaw.
S.TRANSL: that’s why they drove them to near the houses.

S.FORM: avan a kakeḍikeḍian a tangpatsen a sema tapaw, sa kani a mapułat.
avan a kakedrikedrian a tangpacen a sema tapaw, sa kani a mapoljat.
S.TRANSL: The little ones were carried in the mouth to the houses, and were all eaten.

S.FORM: manu sema pairang a tsautsau a maḍusa mareqali.
mano sema pairang a caocao a madrosa mareqali.
S.TRANSL: Two men friends went down to the plains.

S.FORM: manu djumaken nazua vatu, sa katsi, sa patsay azua tsautsau a maḍusa.
mano djomaken nazoa vato, sa kaci, sa pacay azoa caocao a madrosa.
S.TRANSL: Some dogs found them and bit them, and both men died.

S.FORM: "aku izua zazua vatu? sałinga aravats," aya a tsautsau.
"ako izoa zazoa vato? saljinga aravac," aya a caocao.
S.TRANSL: People said: “Why are there dogs like that? We would very much like some.”

S.FORM: saka kemats azua.
saka kemac azoa.
manu "tja kudain anga," aya.
mano "tja kodain anga," aya.
S.TRANSL: So they said: “What shall we do?”

S.FORM: saka qemavay, sa paluvluvi tua quvał.
saka qemavay, sa palovlovi toa qovalj.
S.TRANSL: They made dumplings, and mixed hair in with them.

S.FORM: saka keman a vatu, sa katsingas a ałis nua vatu.
saka keman a vato, sa kacingas a aljis noa vato.
S.TRANSL: And when the dogs ate them, their teeth were all stuck up.

S.FORM: sa djekepi nua tsautsau a kuku a ḍusa, a uqałay a ita, a vavayan a ita; sa vaikan anga a sema a paqaluqalu.
sa djekepi noa caocao a koko a drosa, a oqaljay a ita, a vavayan a ita; sa vaikan anga a sema a paqaloqalo.
S.TRANSL: So the people took two puppies, one male and one female; and they took them off to the East Paiwan area.

S.FORM: sa puałak anga, sa puvatu anga a tsautsau, aya a tjautsikel.
sa poaljak anga, sa povato anga a caocao, aya a tjaocikel.
S.TRANSL: The dogs had puppies, and so people got dogs, according to the story.
